block.p: Japan's New Leader Plans a Full-Fledged Army Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, in his first day in office, moved to reassure Japan's neighbors about nationalist currents in his country, while reaffirming a campaign promise to create a regular army. But he emphasized that the alliance with the United States remained the pillar of Japan's security policy and said he favored a more active role in international peacekeeping, something long urged by the United States.

But he emphasized that the alliance with the United States remained the pillar of Japan's security policy and said he favored a more active role in international peacekeeping, something long urged by the United States.

No Consensus on 'One China' China and Taiwan called for new talks, eight years after they began a historic but ultimately aborted dialogue on future relations. But the new pleas appeared hollow, as neither side signaled compromise on Beijing's precondition that Taiwan agree that it remains part of ''one China.''

Cyberspace Attack Alert The F.B.I. warned that Chinese computer hackers might soon mount strikes against American Web sites, and Pentagon officials ordered stronger safeguards for Defense Department systems. Independent monitors say hackers in both countries have made cyberspace attacks.

Inquiry Into C.I.A. Contractor Congressional officials say they are examining the role played by C.I.A. contract employees from Aviation Development, a company in Montgomery, Ala., as part of an investigation of Peru's downing of a flight carrying American missionaries.

American Sentenced in Russia John Edward Tobin, a visiting American Fulbright scholar at Voronezh State University, was convicted of drug charges and sentenced to 37 months in a penal colony, putting an official stamp on a seemingly minor marijuana infraction that briefly raised suggestions of espionage.

Aid Workers Killed in Congo Six workers of the International Committee of the Red Cross were shot and hacked to death in northeast Congo. A Red Cross spokesman said the organization did not know who had carried out the attack, the worst on the group's staff in five years.

Navy Returns to Vieques; Hundreds Mount Protests The Navy resumed military exercises on the Puerto Rican island, sparking angry demonstrations and civil disobedience by hundreds demanding an end to bombing practice that they say harms the island's ecology and its residents' health. At least 44 people were arrested.

New Approach on Warming The Bush administration, seeking a new strategy on global warming in the aftermath of its rejection of an international climate treaty, has been seeking advice from an array of scientists, economists, business representatives and policy experts.

What Hitler's Doctor Thought The C.I.A. released files on several Nazis, with one document saying Hitler's own doctor believed in 1937 that the Nazi leader was a ''border case between genius and insanity'' with the potential of becoming the ''craziest criminal the world ever knew.''

Warning on Jet's Fuel Pump The F.A.A. told airlines to stop using a fuel pump on the Boeing 737 in certain circumstances after concluding it might have figured in the explosion of a plane at a gate in Bangkok.

Suspect Talked of 'Bomb' Jurors in the Birmingham church bombing trial heard a secretly recorded audiotape featuring the defendant, Thomas E. Blanton Jr., explaining to his wife at the time that he had gone to a Klan meeting to ''plan the bomb.'' But the tape offered no other detail linking him to the blast, which killed four black girls.

4 Die in School Bus Crash A bus carrying middle-school band members from Newton, Mass., to a music festival in Nova Scotia ran off a highway ramp in New Brunswick, Canada, killing four students and injuring several others.
Space Station Computers Ailing NASA engineers scrambled to get key computers working aboard the International Space Station, which has been crippled by the perplexing problem for much of this week.

Club Owners New Targets In Drug Enforcement Effort Law enforcement agencies and local governments around the country, frustrated by the rising popularity of Ecstasy and other illegal drugs among young nightclub revelers, are increasingly going after the clubs themselves with an array of legal tactics that club owners and some civil rights lawyers question.

No Guns for Diallo Officers The four police officers involved in the killing of Amadou Diallo will not be given back their guns for the foreseeable future, Commissioner Bernard H. Kerik said. After Mr. Kerik's announcement, the Fire Department said it had decided to accept an application for firefighter from one of the officers, Edward McMellon.

Mixed Report on Homeless Justice Helen E. Freedman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan said the city had redoubled efforts to put together stable shelter or permanent housing for homeless families after Mayor Giuliani was threatened with contempt of court. Still, she said the city's treatment of the families continued to violate her orders.

Manhunt Ends in Canada Christopher Rocancourt, who jumped bail in the Hamptons nine months ago, running from accusations that he had bilked the well-to-do of nearly $1 million while posing as a Rockefeller, was arrested in western Canada late Thursday.

G.O.P. Primary Maneuverings Bret D. Schundler suffered twin setbacks when a New Jersey refused to stop Bob Franks from entering the Republican primary for governor, and state election officials let Mr. Franks receive up to $720,000 left unspent by Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco's aborted campaign.

Economy Proves Resilient The economy grew at a 2 percent annual rate in the first three months of the year, compared with a 1 percent rate in the fourth quarter of 2000, extending the longest American expansion on record to a full 10 years.

Airline Antitrust Suit Voided A federal judge dismissed a major antitrust case in which the Justice Department had accused American Airlines of driving three competitors out of Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport by undercutting fares.

Delta Pact May Be in Trouble Some Delta pilots are predicting that their union's governing board, which meets in Atlanta starting today, will reject a tentative new contract before union members can vote on it.
Baby-Food Merger Blocked A federal appeals panel upheld an F.T.C. challenge to H. J. Heinz's proposed $185 million acquisition of Milnot Holdings, maker of Beech-Nut.

I.P.O. Price Investigation Securities regulators are gathering information from Wall Street firms in an inquiry into whether prices of new stock offerings were manipulated at the height of the 90's boom.
